title: Barron Hilton, Son of Hotel Chain’s Founder, Escaped Father’s Huge Shadow
text:
Barron Hilton, the second son of the famous hotel chain’s founder, was determined to emerge from his father’s monumental shadow.

Mr. Hilton, who died Thursday at age 91 at his home in Los Angeles, turned down his father’s offer to join Hilton Hotels after serving as a Navy photographer during World War II.

Instead, he went into business for himself as a distributor of fruit juice.

Though he finally joined Hilton in the early 1950s, he continued to pursue other entrepreneurial projects, including an aircraft-leasing company.

In 1959, he helped form the American Football League as the founding owner of the Los Angeles Chargers, who soon relocated to San Diego before returning to their original home two years ago.

His father, Conrad Hilton —who began building his hotel empire with a single hotel in Cisco, Texas in 1919—was known for high living and married three times, including once to Zsa Zsa Gabor.

Barron’s older brother, Nicky, was briefly married to Elizabeth Taylor. Paris Hilton, one of Barron Hilton’s grandchildren, became a reality-television star and tabloid sensation.

Barron Hilton, by contrast, preferred duck hunting to high society. He married his childhood sweetheart, Marilyn Hawley. They had eight children and remained married when she died in 2004.

Owning the Chargers was one of his few public indulgences. “The happiest days of my life were the days I was involved with the Chargers,” he told the Los Angeles Times in 2009. During that period, he helped negotiate the merger of the AFL and the National Football League.

He sold a controlling stake in the Chargers for $10 million to focus on his duties at Hilton Hotels in 1966, when he succeeded his father as chief executive.

Barron Hilton, top right, in 1966 with Colorado’s then Gov. John Love, top left, at a meeting on the financing of a new football stadium. Photo: Dave Mathias/The Denver Post/Getty Images

He oversaw the sale of Hilton’s international operations in 1967 to Trans World Corp. in exchange for stock in the airline company, whose value soon plunged.

In the early 1970s, he helped persuade a reluctant board of directors to buy two Nevada casinos, which became the Las Vegas Hilton and Flamingo Hilton, the core of a successful gaming business.

In 1983, Hilton Hotels began building a casino resort in the marina area of Atlantic City. Weeks before the casino’s opening, the New Jersey Casino Control Commission rejected Hilton’s licensing application. Hilton sold the property to Donald Trump.

Conrad Hilton, who died in 1979, left nearly all his fortune, including a 28% stake in Hilton Hotels, to the Conrad N. Hilton Foundation, assigning it to charity with certain conditions. “There is a natural law, a Divine law, that obliges you and me to relieve the suffering, the distressed and the destitute,” the elder Mr. Hilton wrote in the 33rd and final version of his will.

Holding only a 3.4% stake in the company, Barron Hilton embarked on a 10-year legal battle to secure control. He argued that his father didn’t want the company sold to outsiders and that the will granted him an option to acquire the 28% stake for about $165 million.

That claim sparked a series of lawsuits, eventually involving the Roman Catholic Church and several orders of nuns, which stood to benefit as charities.

A 1989 settlement gave Mr. Hilton control of the company. “Hilton vs. the nuns was not the best public relations move,” he later told USA Today.

In 1996, he recruited Stephen F. Bollenbach, a financial wizard who had worked at Walt Disney Co. , to succeed him as CEO of Hilton Hotels.

Blackstone Group LP acquired the hotel company for $20 billion in 2007. Mr. Hilton also announced that he would leave 97% of his wealth to the foundation, a gift projected to increase its endowment to $6.3 billion from $2.9 billion.

Blackstone Group acquired Hilton Hotels Corp. in 2007 for $20 billion; Barron Hilton in 2010. Photo: Jean Baptiste Lacroix/WireImage

William Barron Hilton, known by his middle name, was born Oct. 23, 1927, in Dallas. He moved with his father to Los Angeles in 1937. In his teenage years, he parked cars for hotel guests at the Town House in Los Angeles.

He joined the Navy at 17 and was stationed in Pearl Harbor, where he worked in a photo lab making I.D. cards for servicemen.

While in the Navy and later at the University of Southern California, he trained as a pilot. He eventually amassed his own small air force—including an acrobatic biplane, a Beechcraft Staggerwing, four gliders and a hot-air balloon—at his 460,000-acre Nevada ranch.

Mr. Hilton is survived by eight children, 15 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.

Write to James R. Hagerty at bob.hagerty@wsj.com
description: Barron Hilton resisted early pressure to join the hotel company created by his father, Conrad Hilton, but eventually led Hilton Hotels Corp. into the Las Vegas casino business.
